author: Karen Halabi
title: Pandaw’s river cruising fleet takes visitors to the remote reaches of the Chindwin and Irrawaddy rivers in Myanmar
text:
THE RV Katha Pandaw slices silently through the water. The only sounds are birdcall, the putter of small fishing craft as they pass, and the splash of fish as they are caught in nets.
Cruising upriver we pass some of the oldest wooden villages in Myanmar as we venture into the remotest and most northerly navigable points on the Chindwin River, almost to the border with India, then on to the Upper Irrawaddy, close to China, and down again. Our adventures take us deep into Myanmar to places with romantic names such as Ava, Amapura, Mingun, Monywa, Inn-ywa, Mawlaik and Tagaung Ancient City.
It’s as if we’ve entered a time warp. The river people have no electricity or modern conveniences. Villagers sleep on rattan mats in stilt houses.
The RV Katha Pandaw is part of Asian cruise company Pandaw’s fleet of nine brass and teak steamers, replicas of the old colonial steamers that used to ply the Irrawaddy as part of the former Irrawaddy Flotilla Company. Myanmar (Burma), Sagaing division, Monywa, Bodhi Tataung. Source: Supplied
When news spreads that we are about to dock, a whole village rushes down to the banks. Eager hands reach out to offer us fruit and flowers. With only a few boat visits each year, it is a rare opportunity for the locals to see foreigners.
Most memorable are stops at remote villages not even marked on maps.
Toothy red betel nut grins and ghostly, thanaka-painted faces are everywhere. Made from grinding the root of a tree, the paste is a beautifier and sun protection all in one.
Each day, when our boat pulls into shore to yet another isolated village, the crew hack steps into the muddy embankment. We grab hats, good walking shoes and scramble ashore on foot to explore the village.
Pandaw’s clientele are mature-aged, well-heeled and enjoy travelling in comfort but intrepid enough to enjoy a bit of adventure and a good slosh through the mud in their Kathmandu gear or Panama hats and waterproof boots. No lying around a hotel pool sipping cocktails for them.
The sights keep coming: the ancient teak carved wooden monasteries in Mandalay (the Golden Palace Monastery or Shwe Nan Daw Kyaung), at Innwa (Bagaya Kyanug monastery) and at Kan.; the Shan enclave of Sitthaung; Pagan with its more than 4000 temples, including Shwezigon; the huge unfinished stupa Mingun Paya and Mingun Bell, the second largest in the world, U Bein, the world’s longest teak wooden bridge at Amarapura and an iconic image on postcards of Myanmar. Woman with bicycle crossing U Bein Bridge. Source: Supplied
At Monywa, about 135km west of Mandalay on the Chindwin River, Phowintaung Hill is a complex of 947 limestone meditation caves with Buddha statues and mural paintings, on a scale that reminds me of Angkor Wat, yet most people, except a few art historians, have never heard of it.
Here I see the world’s longest reclining Buddha. Just south of Monywa is the incredible golden pagoda, Moe Hnyin Than Boaddai (Thanboddhay Paya) covered in more than 500,000 Buddha statues and, nearby at Bodhi Thataung, the 125m Giant Standing Buddha and the largest Reclining Buddha in the world (taller than Christ the Redeemer in Rio).
Finally, the Katha reaches as far as it can go. We are in the most northern navigable reaches of the Irrawaddy in Kachin State at Katha, one of the most difficult places to get to in the rugged precincts of northern Myanmar, and the setting for George Orwell’s novel, Burmese Days .
My lasting memories of Myanmar are of the gold leaf spires on the stupas that line the river and in every village, no matter how poor, and the people — the women pedalling ancient sewing machines, the barefoot men in conical hats ploughing rice paddies behind oxen, and villagers washing their bodies and their clothes in the river. The temples at Bagan. Picture: Karen Halabi Source: Supplied
The contrast between the simple, ingenuous and guileless people of the river and those more worldly and commercial folk who line the shores and markets of the larger ports such as Yangon, Mandalay and Bagan trying to sell you something, is striking.
I feel privileged to have seen Myanmar before tourism engulfs it. And you can too. Get in early before the magic is lost.

MYANMAR
Pandaw offers a 10-night cruise of Pagan and the Upper Irrawaddy, Pagan-Katha-Mandalay and a 20-night Chindwin and Upper Irrawaddy cruise in Yangon/Kalewa-Katha-Mandalay.
Prices start from $5090 a person for the 10-night cruise or $9970 a person for the 20-night cruise. Local alcohol, drinks and tips for crew, daily excursions, and a flight from Yangon to Kalewa for the start of the cruise are included in the price. Meals alternate between buffet breakfasts and a silver service la carte lunch and dinners.
